text: Hi folks, and welcome to this week's
news and community spotlights. We're
excited to announce a major update to
Unreal Engine 5.6 templates designed to
help you hit the ground running.
Templates have been significantly
reduced in size, helping decrease engine
download times while also increasing the
number of features in each template. A
brand new option, variance, allows you
to extend templates for specific types
of gameplay. Whether you're prototyping
a sidescrolling platformer, building an
openw world racing game, or crafting a
top-own strategy title, variants offer a
more specific tailored starting point to
help bring your vision to life. The
following core templates have been
refreshed with optional variants.
Firsterson now includes firsterson
rendering features for independent field
of view, scale, and lighting. A full
character has also been implemented. No
more floating arms along with a custom
control rig to handle warping to a
firstperson view. The basic firstperson
template has had weapons removed to
reduce initial content when loading the
lightweight firsterson template and
includes two different variant options.
The first is a horror variant. This
version added a torch to the player
pawn, an example map that demonstrates
best practice when lighting dark
environments, a sprint mechanic with
associated UI, and a flickering light
setup. The second is a shooter variant.
This version added a range of weapon
pickups, a range of bullet types,
multiple AI opponents, ammo UI, and an
example map as well. The base thirdp
person template has remained mostly
unchanged, but has been extended in the
combat, sidescroller, and platform
variants. The combat variant includes
simple hand combat, combo attacks, AI,
in world health bar UI, and an example
combat map. The sidescroller variant
provides a fixed camera example,
constrained plane setup, pickups,
single-sided and drop through collision
interaction, fixed to floor and locked
camera examples, and an example side
scrolling map. Then lastly, the
platformer variant has a dash mechanic,
wall jump, an example platforming map
for testing out those moves. The base
top-down template has remained mostly
unchanged, but has been extended in the
strategy and twin stick variants. The
strategy variants now includes drag
selected AI characters, simple character
interactions, a roof transition effect,
simple AI move to examples, and an
orthographic camera setup. The twin
stick template has simple AI opponents,
a bomb and shoot mechanic, simple arena
map along with score and multiplier UI.
The base vehicle template has been
updated. Now the vehicle templates are
made up of separate static mesh pieces
connected to a skeleton. We've also
simplified the vehicle materials and
textures. There are two blueprints
available that show how to spawn static
and spline meshes, but these will be
replaced with PCG once it's fully
released. Additionally, runtime virtual
textures has been enabled and set up for
each map in the project. The first
variant, off-road, features an openw
world exploration map, an off-road
all-wheel drive vehicle example, spline
roads, and HLOD structure. Though keep
in mind HLODS have not been built to
save memory. Next up is the time trial
variant which includes a simple track
map gate structure setup to mark
traversal through a lap along with time
and best time UI. In addition to new
template variants, shared content
between variants has also been updated
as well. For level prototyping, meshes
have been updated to nanite quality as
well as a door, jumpad, and physics
dummy have been added under
interactables. Our classic heroes, Manny
and Quinn, have both had materials and
textures optimized, plus have been
provided a new set of animations such as
unarmed, armed, dash, combat, hit,
death, and so on. A new input pack has
been added that standardizes input
across templates, demonstrates mobile
touch input setup, and added a widget
touch thumb stick. Then lastly, we've
added more weapons with optimized
textures and materials such as a pistol,
rifle, and grenade launcher. Templates
can now be created from the new project
screen. Use the variant drop-own menu to
select which variant you want to use per
template. If you prefer a more basic
option, choose none to use a lightweight
version of the template. Try them out
and let us know what you think.
Did you hear? Starting now, for any Epic
Games Store payments we process,
developers will pay a 0% revenue share
on their first $1 million in revenue per
app per year and then our regular 88/12%
revenue share when they earn more than
that. Also, we are releasing a new
feature enabling developers to launch
their own web shops hosted by the Epic
Game Store. These web shops can offer
players out of app purchases as a more
cost-effective alternative to in-app
purchases. With new legal rulings in
place, developers will be able to send
players from games to make digital
purchases from web shops on any platform
that allows it, including iOS in the
European Union and United States.
There's never been a better time to see
if Epic services are right for you.
Join your local chapter to grow, learn,
and be inspired. Here are upcoming
events to check out.
Now, let's dig into this week's
incredible community spotlights. Where
Crimson Fell by Kol Goodbrand is a
stunning environment scene that is
impactful in its simplicity. Using a
combination of hand sculpted textures as
well as some clever shaders such as this
world aligned barnacle, we are genuinely
immersed into what feels like just a
snapshot of a full world. In the
artist's own words, "The sea drank their
voices long ago, yet the wind still
catches on their crimson, tattered but
defiant. What kind of people built
towards the sun only to be buried by the
tide? I have not found the heart of this
place, but I feel it watching." Check
out the full piece on their art station.
Jester by Resa Akari is a 3D rendition
of the concept art Reign of Dystopian by
Za Xhiao. This vibrant character piece
was created as a final project during
the advanced term at Thinktank Training
Center developed over 16 weeks of
focused creative exploration. More than
just an assignment, it was a playful yet
ambitious dive into blending
professional experience with personal
R&D, all while experimenting with new
tools and advanced techniques. The goal
to bring a game ready character to life.
One that not only stays true to its
original concept, but also reflects a
bold stylized vision of what's possible.
The look and feel were inspired by a
whimsical painterly charm of South of
Midnight and the enchanting atmosphere
of the cancelled Project Black,
capturing a rich mix of stylized realism
and folklore flare. Built in Unreal
Engine 5, the final shots sparkle with
moody lighting and lush environment
details, courtesy of the Quixle Mega
Scans Dark Ruins pan. Turnarounds and
beauty renders polished with the flipped
Normal portfolio setup round out this
dynamic showcase of both technical skill
and artistic joy. You can check out the
full project as well as breakdowns on
their art station page.
Flower Town by Cha Severly Vang is a
cheerful and whimsical environment scene
that radiates charm and sunshine,
capturing the essence of a cozy stylized
world. Created over the course of 5
months using Unreal Engine 5, the
project showcases a thoughtful blend of
artistry and technique. Built with
modular pieces and enriched by hand
painted plant textures, it brings a
vibrant landscape to life with clever
touches like in engine hue variations
for lush buried vegetation. A mix of
custom textures crafted in Substance
Designer adds depth and detail, tying
the scene together with a polished
storybook feel. From its playful design
to its homey atmosphere, this piece is a
joyful celebration of imaginative worldb
buildinging and creative dedication.
Thanks for watching this week's news and
community spotlights. I'll catch you
next week.
